items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: Dynamic import maps
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): whatwg/html#10528
  • Explainer URL (if available): whatwg/html#10528 (comment)
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @yoavweiss
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @smaug---- @zcorpan
  • WebKit standards-position: WebKit/standards-positions#381

Other information

Import maps currently have to load before any ES module and there can only be a single import map per document. That makes them fragile and potentially slow to use in real-life scenarios: Any module that loads before them breaks the entire app, and in apps with many modules the become a large blocking resource, as the entire map for all possible modules needs to load first.

This proposal is to enable multiple import maps per document, by merging them in a consistent and deterministic way.
items.title: Dynamic import maps

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: CSS reading-flow
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://drafts.csswg.org/css-display-4/#reading-flow
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/dizhang168/reading-order-items
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @dizhang168, @mfreed7, @rachelandrew
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @emilio
  • WebKit standards-position: WebKit/standards-positions#378

Other information

The CSS Working Group has resolved to add the new reading-flow property (w3c/csswg-drafts#8589, spec) to enable focus navigation in visual order for layout items that might not be displayed in source order (such as grid, flex and masonry items). Chromium is implementing the new property and opened a whatwg/html#10407 on the needed HTML spec change.

We would like to seek Mozilla's position on implementing the CSS property.

Further, we would like to get feedback on the suggested HTML proposal and the open questions on display: contents (w3c/csswg-drafts#9230, whatwg/html#10533).
items.title: CSS reading-flow

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: getComposedRanges()
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://w3c.github.io/selection-api/#dom-selection-getcomposedranges
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/mfreed7/shadow-dom-selection
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @dizhang168 @mfreed7 @siliu1
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @sefeng211 @emilio
  • WebKit standards-position: WebKit/standards-positions#376

Other information

Current getComposedRanges API has single shadowRoots parameter which is a rest parameter. We propose changing it to a dictionary that contains an array of shadow roots to be consistent with other shadow DOM API:

  • getHTML()
  • caretPositionFromPoint()

We would also like to add selectionRoot. This argument "scopes" the selection, so that the returned selection endpoints are always descendants of element.

Proposed change:

sequence<StaticRange> getComposedRanges(optional GetComposedRangesOptions options = {});

dictionary GetComposedRangesOptions {
  sequence<ShadowRoot> shadowRoots = [];
  ShadowRoot selectionRoot;
};

Further, we need to re-evaluate API changes for the Range and StaticRange interface, to support nodes in different tree. Either we need to update existing definitions or we might need to add new interfaces. Help us resolve these discussions.

See:
Changes to Range, StaticRange: w3c/selection-api#169
Change getComposedRanges’ parameter to a dictionary: w3c/selection-api#176
Change getComposedRanges to have selectionRoot parameter: w3c/selection-api#180
Main: w3c/selection-api#161
items.title: Selection API: getComposedRanges

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: CSS Box Sizing Module Level 4 (specifically the section on stretch)
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://drafts.csswg.org/css-sizing-4/#valdef-width-stretch
  • Explainer URL (if available): N/A
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @tabatkins, @fantasai, @jensimmons
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional): https://caniuse.com/mdn-css_properties_width_stretch
  • Bugzilla URL (optional): https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1789477
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): myself, @emilio
  • WebKit standards-position: None filed yet that I could find.

Other information

The stretch keyword is a standardized version of the behavior that's traditionally been exposed by the prefixed -moz-available and -webkit-fill-available CSS keywords. (Minor caveat: -moz-available only works in the inline axis for now, but stretch and -webkit-fill-available work in both axes.) We've observed that there are webcompat requirements for us to implement -webkit-fill-available, and it seems the best way forward is to implement the standardized stretch behavior and use -webkit-fill-available as an alias for it (while recommending that sites use the standard keyword from here on out).

(@bfgeek noted in web-platform-tests/interop-2022-viewport#18 (comment) that Chromium at least has been moving towards making -webkit-fill-available the same as the standardized stretch behavior.)
items.title: [css-sizing-4] `stretch` keyword for sizing properties

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: Filter Effects
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://drafts.fxtf.org/filter-effects-2/#backdrop-filter-operation
  • Explainer URL (if available): w3c/fxtf-drafts#374
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @flackr
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional): N/A (this is a change to the way backdrop-filter renders)
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional):
  • WebKit standards-position: WebKit/standards-positions#372

Other information

This is specifically about the switch from the duplicate edgeMode to the mirror edgeMode for backdrop-filter sampling beyond the backdrop edges. The duplicate edgeMode leads to significant flickering in common scenarios and significantly overweights pixels at the edge into the blur, whereas mirroring back into the backdrop allows the smooth introduction of new content into the backdrop while still avoiding sampling outside of it (the motivation for using duplicate originally).
items.title: Backdrop filter mirror edgeMode

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: Add ability to trigger autofill on form elements in webdriver-bidi specs
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): w3c/webdriver-bidi#706
  • Explainer URL (if available): w3c/webdriver#1796
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @yoavweiss @martinLechnerShopify
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @whimboo @galich @jgraham
  • WebKit standards-position: WebKit/standards-positions#371

Other information

Currently there is no way for developers to automate autofill in browsers and thus they can't test their HTML with the browser's autofill behaviour. Adding such an API would allow such testing and enable developers to write automated autofill tests (e.g. WPT).
items.title: Add ability to trigger autofill on form elements in webdriver-bidi specs

Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: § 5.1 Transferable MediaStreamTrack, from Media Capture and Streams Extensions
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://w3c.github.io/mediacapture-extensions/#transferable-mediastreamtrack
  • Explainer URL (if available):
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @youennf
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional): https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=267682, https://bugzil.la/1749543
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @jan-ivar
  • WebKit standards-position:

Other information

Filed from news in https://webkit.org/blog/15443/news-from-wwdc24-webkit-in-safari-18-beta:

WebKit for Safari 18 beta adds support for MediaStreamTrack processing in a dedicated worker.

Transfer of MST is a prerequisite for the APIs MediaStreamTrackProcessor and VideoTrackGenerator, which in the spec are only exposed in DedicatedWorker.
items.title: Transferable MediaStreamTrack (Media Capture and Streams Extension)

Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: Prioritized Task Scheduling: scheduler.yield()
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://wicg.github.io/scheduling-apis/#dom-scheduler-yield
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/WICG/scheduling-apis/blob/main/explainers/prioritized-task-scheduling.md#scheduleryield
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @shaseley
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @smaug---- @sefeng211
  • WebKit standards-position: WebKit/standards-positions#361

Other information

This builds on scheduler.postTask(), which I know has been prototyped but not shipped in Gecko. We recently landed WICG/scheduling-apis#92 to try to address concerns captured in WICG/scheduling-apis#67. That same concern will apply to this API, which builds on the existing prioritization in the spec.
items.title: Prioritized Task Scheduling: scheduler.yield()

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: WebAssembly ESM Integration
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://github.com/webassembly/esm-integration
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/WebAssembly/esm-integration/blob/main/proposals/esm-integration/README.md
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @linclark, @littledan, @Ms2ger, @takikawa, @guybedford
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional): https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1899832
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @codehag @eqrion
  • WebKit standards-position:

Other information

The WebAssembly ESM Integration allows JS modules to import Wasm and vice versa, providing improved ergonomics and tooling workflows when working with WebAssembly modules. With Source Phase Imports it also allows the ability to import uninstantiated Wasm through the module system enabling these benefits for the full range of instantiation workflows. While it has been in development for some time, it was recently progressed to Phase 3 in the WebAssembly process.
items.title: WebAssembly ESM Integration

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: ServiceWorkerAutoPreload
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available):
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/service-worker-auto-preload
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @sisidovski
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional):
  • WebKit standards-position: WebKit/standards-positions#359

Other information

This API is a new loading strategy for ServiceWorker. ServiceWorkerAutoPreload is a mode where the browser issues a network request (i.e. a regular request which may result in a HTTP cache hit or an actual fetch) in parallel with the ServiceWorker bootstrap, and consumes the network request result inside the fetch handler.

The status in chromium can be tracked from https://chromestatus.com/feature/5194817700364288

This is an early-stage idea but we'd love early engagement from other implementers.
items.title: ServiceWorkerAutoPreload
